image.altText: A smiling woman with white hair

items.synopsis: Clare Nowland fell and fractured her skull last week, after she was tasered by the senior constable who had been called to her aged-care home in Cooma, because she was carrying a knife.

title.children: Senior constable suspended after tasering 95yo NSW great-grandmother

image.altText: Close-up selfie of man with shaved head.

items.synopsis: A manhunt is underway after Marvin Oraiha, who is believed to be a low-level bikie associate, was shot dead inside his car in south-west Sydney.

title.children: Manhunt launched after gangland shooting murder of 24yo Sydney man

image.altText: People holding umbrellas gather outside an orange terrace house with a for lease sign out the front.

items.synopsis: Property managers are often the only contact point renters have for their landlords, and agents must act in the best interests of their client. As the rental crisis continues, we take a look at who's pulling the strings.

title.children: 'I've got some very greedy landlords at the moment': Behind the scenes of Australia's rental crisis

image.altText: Black letters that spell out PwC on a white wall with red, orange and yellow graphic squares above the letter C.

items.synopsis: A Treasury investigation into the impact of a PwC tax expert's use of confidential information — sold to clients seeking to minimise tax — could lead to the firm being referred to the Australian Federal Police, the assistant treasurer warns.

title.children: PwC breached the Australian government's trust, now it is facing the consequences

image.altText: Narendra Modi stands in front of a crowd of people reaching out to touch him.

items.synopsis: India's leader will address a rally which is expected to draw a crowd of up to 20,000 people who are hoping to catch a glimpse of the prime minister and listen as Mr Modi — a powerful orator — extols the virtues of the Australia-India relationship.

title.children: Thousands from Indian diaspora expected to flock to see Prime Minister Narendra Modi during Australia visit

image.altText: The Tesla gigafactory in Nevada

items.synopsis: Batteries could shape Australia's future from mining to assembly. But industry leaders say we need to act quickly to capitalise on the renewables boom.

title.children: In the old fossil fuel heartlands of Australia, a new kind of industry is being built

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in Perth

items.synopsis: A year after it was elected, there's a lot to celebrate for the Albanese government in delivering its agenda. But some election promises it made are in trouble, writes RMIT ABC Fact Check's Matt Martino.

title.children: Promises can sink prime ministers. A year after the election, here are the ones to watch

image.altText: Two women stand in front of black-and-white photos of rock climbing.

items.synopsis: A court has heard Stephen Mitchell created a web of lies and fabrications in order to sexually assault six little girls who trusted him — this week, the former rock climbing instructor was finally punished.

title.children: Court hears serial paedophile caused 'a life sentence of trauma' for six young girls

image.altText: Richmond Tigers coach Damien Hardwick

items.synopsis: Richmond coach Damien Hardwick is set to announce he is stepping down after 14 seasons. Follow live.

title.children: Damien Hardwick set to announce he is quitting as Richmond coach

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "To my playing group, it was tough before and it is tougher now. "I spoke to you before about how much I loved being your coach and how proud I am of you. "The three stalwarts that here from the start, there are four I think, in Jack, Trent, Dylan and Dustin, you all mean the world to me and I have enjoyed every aspect of being your coach. "I will enjoy... watching you go on with your careers."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hardwick pays tribute to his players

children.content: "To my playing group, it was tough before and it is tougher now.
"I spoke to you before about how much I loved being your coach and how proud I am of you.
"The three stalwarts that here from the start, there are four I think, in Jack, Trent, Dylan and Dustin, you all mean the world to me and I have enjoyed every aspect of being your coach.
"I will enjoy... watching you go on with your careers."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The club confirms Damien Hardwick's departure, and that assistant Andrew McQualter will be the interim coach.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Andrew McQualter to take over as interim coach

children.content: The club confirms Damien Hardwick's departure, and that assistant Andrew McQualter will be the interim coach.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Damien Hardwick says his decision to step down was "one of the hardest conversations" he has had to have. "It has been an incredible ride and one that is coming to an end, but I could not have wished a better place to have my journey as an AFL coach," he said. "The way the club has supported me, gave me every resource possible, get me the best people are possible, it's a testament to what I think we have created."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'It has been an incredible ride': Hardwick thanks Richmond

children.content: Damien Hardwick says his decision to step down was "one of the hardest conversations" he has had to have.
"It has been an incredible ride and one that is coming to an end, but I could not have wished a better place to have my journey as an AFL coach," he said.
"The way the club has supported me, gave me every resource possible, get me the best people are possible, it's a testament to what I think we have created."

image.altText: Stan Grant on Q+A.

items.synopsis: Stan Grant makes an emotional statement at the end of Q+A, announcing he will be stepping away from media commitments following racist abuse, but confirming that he will be back stronger after a break.

title.children: Stan Grant sends a message to his abusers in last Q+A before stepping away

image.altText: A car with a smashed window at night

items.synopsis: A car found burnt out nearby is believed to be connected to the shooting.

title.children: Police sources believe fatal shooting of man in Sydney's south-west is gang-related

image.altText: A person wearing personal protective equipment holding up a SARS COVID-19 rapid antigen test swab

items.synopsis: As the temperature drops, Australia is approaching its fifth COVID wave. This is what it could look like.

title.children: Australia is approaching its fifth COVID-19 wave. What can we expect this time?

image.altText: A train arrives at a platform

items.synopsis: An interim report finds a backlog of almost 40,000 defects plaguing Sydney's "fragile" train network, and things are on track to get worse.

title.children: Backlog of 40,000 defects plaguing Sydney train network, report finds

image.altText: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy disembarks French government plane.

items.synopsis: Western nations have stepped up the provision of weapons to Ukraine. While this will be key to helping Ukraine confront the Russians, there are two other aspects of combat power which are even more vital, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Ukraine's secret ingredient in war with Russia isn't weapons

image.altText: An Afghan family of four standing side by side in their Gold Coast backyard

items.synopsis: Australians are begging the government to rescue their relatives from the Taliban as the processing of refugee applications grinds to a halt for thousands of at-risk Afghan asylum seekers.

title.children: 'They don't just come after you': Afghan Australians beg government to rescue relatives from Taliban

image.altText: On the left, an underwater scene of fish swimming over coral. On the right, a portrait of a woman smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: Dr Emma Flukes is heading up a first-of-its-kind data portal project which will allow marine and armchair scientists to take an in-depth look at what lives on the sea floor around Australia.

title.children: This scientist is using cutting-edge technology to uncover the mysteries of the ocean floor

image.altText: a cafe worker serves customers

items.synopsis: Australia's industrial relations system is like Catch-22. You can't have a pay rise until productivity improves. And productivity can't improve until you get a pay rise, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The great productivity con. Why your pay isn't keeping up with inflation

image.altText: Jason Sotiris and his Angela smiling

items.synopsis: Angela was just one when she was diagnosed with a rare form of cancer. Watching her fight for her life sparked an idea in her father, which is now helping sick kids all over the country.

title.children: How Jason went from Western Sydney tradie to designing clothes for sick kids

image.altText: A picture of the tiktok logo, which looks like a musical note, with a silhouette of a person holding a phone.

items.synopsis: TikTok files a lawsuit challenging the state of Montana's new ban on use of the Chinese-owned short-video app.

title.children: TikTok sues US state of Montana after it moved to ban app

image.altText: US Air Force F-16 fighter jets in the sky.

items.synopsis: The destructive power and global availability of F-16 jets is expected to help break the land warfare slog and shift the balance Ukraine's way, but it's unlikely that will happen anytime soon.

title.children: Here come the jets. Can Western air power shift Ukraine's battlefield balance?

image.altText: Meta logo in background in focus with blurry silhouette heads in foreground.

items.synopsis: Meta is hit with a record 1.2 billion euro ($1.9 billion) fine by its lead privacy regulator in the European Union for its handling of user information and given five months to stop transferring users' data to the United States.

title.children: Meta hit with record $1.9 billion fine over transfer of users' data to United States

image.altText: Tina Arena stands looking at the camera on a stage with dramatic lighting and a piano in the background.

items.synopsis: The Australia Council for the Arts releases a statement saying the ARIA Hall of Fame inductee had stepped down from the government arts funding body "due to her work commitments".

title.children: Largely absent singer Tina Arena resigns from board of Australia Council

image.altText: Two actors (Ryan Corr and Bob Morley) sitting on a ledge looking off into the distance, one in khaki green, the other in colours

items.synopsis: It's not often I'll review an ABC show, but rest assured, if I thought it was trash, I would say so. In Limbo is exquisite, writes Mawunyo Gbogbo.

title.children: The brilliance of In Limbo is in the way it balances humour and tragedy

image.altText: A man holds a turtle up close to the camera

items.synopsis: Scientists have spotted white-throated snapping turtles in Baffle Creek, 100 kilometres north of Bundaberg, for the first time.

title.children: Queensland researchers make surprise discovery of critically endangered bum-breathing turtle

image.altText: A woman with a blonde bob and wearing sunglasses smiles outside court.

items.synopsis: Writer E Jean Carroll is seeking to amend the first of two defamation lawsuits against Donald Trump to demand at least $US10 million ($15 million) in additional damages, citing comments he made on CNN after a jury found him liable for sexually abusing her.

title.children: E Jean Carroll seeks new damages after Trump called her a 'whack job' one day after civil trial verdict

image.altText: Halle and Alison

items.synopsis: Draft international guidelines on polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) highlight how weight stigma — being judged or discriminated against because of our weight — can prevent women from getting the proper treatment and support they deserve.

title.children: The confusing and misunderstood link between body size and PCOS

image.altText: A young girl pushes her hair back from her forehead

items.synopsis: Portuguese police set up an exclusion zone in preparation for a search of a reservoir near the resort Madeleine McCann disappeared from in 2007.

title.children: Police to launch search for Madeleine McCann in Portuguese dam

image.altText: Cradle Mountain Master Plan, cable car

items.synopsis: The Cradle Mountain Cableway is in serious doubt after the Commonwealth withdraws $30 million in funding from the project because the Tasmanian government missed a deadline.

title.children: Malcolm Turnbull gave this Cradle Mountain project $30 million. Five years later, it's been withdrawn

image.altText: Stock image of a woman holding her head in her hands.

items.synopsis: The Escaping Violence Payment wait time period has dropped by 27 days.

title.children: People can get one-off domestic violence payments within six days

image.altText: The tails of Qantas planes showing the flying kangaroo pass each other at Sydney Airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas sees a record pre-tax profit this financial year on the back of strong demand for travel, and the Australian share market gains as US President Joe Biden hosts high-level talks to prevent the United States from defaulting on its debts of about $47.2 trillion.

title.children: Qantas sees $2.5 billion annual profit, ASX higher as Biden resumes high-level talks to prevent US debt default

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is making gains in early trade as the US debt ceiling negotiations continue in the US. The ASX 200 index has put on 0.2 per cent to 7,276, while the All Ordinaries index is also up 0.2 per cent to 7,464. Most sectors are higher on the benchmark index with energy stocks leading the gains after oil prices rose overnight. Gaming firm Tabcorp (+5 per cent) is doing the best, while farming business Elders (-4.8 per cent) is doing the worst.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens higher

children.content: The Australian share market is making gains in early trade as the US debt ceiling negotiations continue in the US.
The ASX 200 index has put on 0.2 per cent to 7,276, while the All Ordinaries index is also up 0.2 per cent to 7,464.
Most sectors are higher on the benchmark index with energy stocks leading the gains after oil prices rose overnight.
Gaming firm Tabcorp (+5 per cent) is doing the best, while farming business Elders (-4.8 per cent) is doing the worst.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has told investors to expect another strong profit, driven by high demand from consumers wanting to travel. The airline is anticipating an underlying profit before tax of between $2.43 billion and $2.48 billion for the current financial year. It has also increased its existing share buyback by up to $100 million. Flying activity increased in the second-half as new aircraft and more wide body jets returned from long-term storage, the company said in a statement. Jet fuel prices remain elevated but recent falls will deliver a cost improvement in the second half, Qantas said. The airline posted an annual underlying loss before tax of $1.86 billion in 2021-22 financial year. But it swung to a record first-half profit, earlier this year, as appetite for travel grew. It also said: "As forecast, the steady return of total market capacity has seen fare levels moderate from peaks reached in the first half of FY23, but yields are expected to remain materially above pre-COVID levels through FY24, particularly internationally." In other words, airfares should get a little cheaper - but they'll still be much higher than they were prior to the coronavirus pandemic. In addition, there will be some changes to management. One of Qantas' directors Michael L'Estrange is retiring from the board. He'll be replaced by Doug Parker - the former chairman and CEO of American Airlines, who has more than 35 years of experience in the aviation industry.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas expects full-year profit of up to $2.48b

children.content: Qantas has told investors to expect another strong profit, driven by high demand from consumers wanting to travel.
The airline is anticipating an underlying profit before tax of between
$2.43 billion and $2.48 billion
for the current financial year.
It has also increased its existing share buyback by up to $100 million.
Flying activity increased in the second-half as new aircraft and more wide body jets returned from long-term storage, the company said in a statement.
Jet fuel prices remain elevated but recent falls will deliver a cost improvement in the second half, Qantas said.
The airline posted an annual underlying loss before tax of $1.86 billion in 2021-22 financial year. But it swung to a record first-half profit, earlier this year, as appetite for travel grew.
It also said:

"As forecast, the steady return of total market capacity has seen fare levels moderate from peaks reached in the first half of FY23, but yields are expected to remain materially above pre-COVID levels through FY24, particularly internationally."
In other words, airfares should get a little cheaper - but they'll still be much higher than they were prior to the coronavirus pandemic.
In addition, there will be some changes to management.
One of Qantas' directors Michael L'Estrange is retiring from the board.
He'll be replaced by Doug Parker - the former chairman and CEO of American Airlines, who has more than 35 years of experience in the aviation industry.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy have held another meeting in the White House about raising the US government's $US31.4 trillion debt ceiling. The US economy is at risk of crashing if no deal is reached in 10 days. The Democratic president and the top congressional Republican have struggled to make progress on an agreement, as McCarthy is pressuring the White House to agree to spending cuts in the federal budget that Biden has called "extreme". They have until June 1 to increase the government's self-borrowing limit or trigger an unprecedented debt default that economists warn could bring on a recession. Biden told reporters as the meeting started that he was "optimistic" they could make some progress. Both sides need a bipartisan agreement to "sell it" to their constituencies, he said, adding there may still be some disagreements. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen on Monday offered a sobering reminder of how little time is left, saying the earliest estimated default date remains June 1 and that it is "highly likely" that Treasury will no longer be able to pay all government obligations by early June if the debt ceiling is not raised. White House aides met with Republican negotiators on Capitol Hill for two hours on Monday, and early indications were that the talks had gone well. "I firmly believe what we're negotiating right now, a majority of Republicans will see that it is a right place to put us on the right path," McCarthy told reporters. Any deal to raise the limit must pass both chambers of Congress, and therefore hinges on bipartisan support. McCarthy's Republicans control the House 222-213, while Biden's Democrats hold the Senate 51-49. A failure to lift the debt ceiling would trigger a default that would shake financial markets and drive interest rates higher on everything from car payments to credit cards.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: President Joe Biden holds further talks to avoid US debt default

children.content: US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy have held another meeting in the White House about raising the US government's $US31.4 trillion debt ceiling.
The US economy is at risk of crashing if no deal is reached in 10 days.

The Democratic president and the top congressional Republican have struggled to make progress on an agreement, as McCarthy is pressuring the White House to agree to spending cuts in the federal budget that Biden has called "extreme".

props.alt: Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and US President Joe Biden talking to each other in the White House.

children.content: Kevin McCarthy and Joe Biden meeting to discuss US debt ceiling.
(Reuters: Leah Millis)
They have until
June 1
to increase the government's self-borrowing limit or trigger an unprecedented debt default that economists warn could bring on a recession.

Biden told reporters as the meeting started that he was "optimistic" they could make some progress. Both sides need a bipartisan agreement to "sell it" to their constituencies, he said, adding there may still be some disagreements.
Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen on Monday offered a sobering reminder

of how little time is left, saying the earliest estimated default date remains June 1 and that it is "highly likely" that Treasury will no longer be able to pay all government obligations by early June if the debt ceiling is not raised.
White House aides met with Republican negotiators on Capitol Hill for two hours on Monday, and early indications were that the talks had gone well.
"I firmly believe what we're negotiating right now, a majority of Republicans will see that it is a right place to put us on the right path," McCarthy told reporters.
Any deal to raise the limit must pass both chambers of Congress, and therefore hinges on bipartisan support.
McCarthy's Republicans control the House 222-213, while Biden's Democrats hold the Senate 51-49.
A failure to lift the debt ceiling would trigger a default that would shake financial markets and drive interest rates higher on everything from car payments to credit cards.

image.altText: Blues and orange colours flecked with the stars.

items.synopsis: Sonification is a way to understand astronomical data through sounds. These experts say it's also a good way to understand the mechanics of outer space.

title.children: What does a galaxy 'sound' like? Sonification is a way for more people to engage with astronomy
